A series of supported EuOCl catalysts, and bulk EuOCl catalyst were selected for ethylene oxychlorination with HCl to produce a VCM. The supported EuOCl catalysts showed higher ethylene conversion and VCM yield than those of bulk EuOCl despite the low Eu content. The EuOCl/Y catalysts demonstrated the highest ethylene conversion and VCM selectivity followed by EuOCl/Al2O3. The catalysts were characterized in terms of redox properties, acidic properties, and adsorption behavior of the reactant and product. The reduction temperature of europium species decreased when EuOCl was loaded on various supports. The activity of HCl oxidation is strongly related to the improved redox properties, resulting in better activation of the reactant. We demonstrated that the number of acidic sites was proportional to the dehydrochlorination activity of EDC. Investigation of the adsorption behavior of C2H4 showed that the number of oxygen vacancies increased on the supported EuOCl catalysts. EuOCl/Y and EuOCl/Al2O3 catalysts, showed good catalytic performance, exhibited better redox and acidic properties, and had higher amounts of oxygen vacancies than the other catalysts. However, EuOCl/Y with excessively high acidity showed deactivation with time-on-stream owing to carbon deposition. Therefore, EuOCl/Al2O3 was found to be the most suitable supported catalyst for the oxychlorination of ethylene. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethylene oxychlorination Direct production of VCM from ethylene Europium oxychloride Support effect 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is one of the most important polymeric materials used in various industries. PVC has excellent flame retardancy, durability, oil resistance, and chemical resistance. Moreover, because it is comprised of 60% chlorine from industrial salts, it is an energy-saving plastic which conserves oil resources [1–3]. PVC is produced by the polymerization of the vinyl chloride monomer (VCM). Currently, the commercial process for producing VCM can be classified into two types: acetylene hydrochlorination and a balanced process involving oxychlorination of ethylene and chlorination of ethylene [2–5]. Except for regions such as China, where acetylene can be supplied cheaply from coal, most of the processes producing VCM use ethylene as a feedstock. The process of producing VCM from ethylene consists of two steps. The first step is the ethylene oxychlorination process, where ethylene reacts with oxygen and HCl over promoted CuCl2/Al2O3, producing 1, 2-dichloroethane (EDC) [6–12]. The second step is the non-catalytic thermal cracking of EDC forming VCM above 500 °C [8–10,13,14]. Although these processes produce high yields of VCM, there are some disadvantages that lead to a reduction in the efficiency of the process. Volatilization and particle agglomeration of cupric chloride species are the main limitations of this process. Although the cupric chloride species have high activity transferring Cl to ethylene, gradual loss of the active phase of the catalysts occurs as the reaction proceeds because of its volatility and low melting point [6–12]. The instability of cupric chloride can be suppressed by adding promoters such as alkali metals (Na, K) and alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca), however, the effect of promoters is insufficient to prevent CuCl2 loss [15–20]. To overcome the limitation of instability of CuCl2 based catalysts, various attempts have been made to discover new active phases with a stable structures and high activity [21]. Recently, it was reported that bulk CeO2 and EuOCl-based catalysts exhibited good activity in ethylene oxychlorination while maintaining a stable structure [22,23]. Additionally, it was discovered that bulk CeO2 and EuOCl catalysts directly produce VCM with high selectivity via oxychlorination of ethylene with HCl and O2. These unique features of the catalysts are considered an opportunity to develop an efficient process to produce VCM from ethylene by removing the EDC thermal cracking process, which is the most energy-intensive part of the entire process. In particular, bulk EuOCl catalysts are less active but highly selective toward VCM compared to bulk CeO2 catalysts. They also display a low selectivity toward carbon oxides (COx) originating from overoxidation [23]. However, the higher cost of europium compared to that of ceria limits the chances of its potential commercial success. In previous studies, bulk EuOCl catalysts were synthesized by the precipitation method, which showed a low yield of catalysts compared to the amount of europium precursor used [23]. These drawbacks make it difficult to apply europium catalysts to ethylene oxychlorination. In the case of CuCl2-based catalyst, there have been many studies on the support effect to improve the stability and performance of the catalyst [7,8,10,18]. Vajglová et al. reported that the characteristic of the support has a significant effect on catalytic performance of CuCl2-based catalyst [24]. Therefore, this study aims to develop highly selective supported EuOCl catalysts for the direct production of VCM from ethylene oxychlorination. First, EuOCl was impregnated on various supports such as γ-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, SiO2 and Y zeolite, to achieve a high Eu atom economy. In addition, the physicochemical properties and elementary reactions such as HCl oxidation and EDC dehydrochlorination of the supported catalyst were investigated to elucidate the role of the catalytic function in the reaction pathway. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Supports such as Al2O3 (SBA-200, Sasol), TiO2 (P25, Degussa), SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich), ZrO2 (Sigma-Aldrich), and zeolite Y (CBV 760, Zeolyst, SiO2/Al2O3 = 60) were calcined at 550 °C prior to impregnation. For comparison, bulk EuOCl was synthesized using the precipitation method, following the process reported in the literature [23]. Briefly, europium nitrate (Eu(NO3)3∙6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%)) was dissolved in deionized water under stirring and the precipitation was achieved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH4OH (Samchun, 30%) until a pH of 10.5 was reached. The slurry was stirred for 4 h and washed with deionized water. After filtration, the precipitate was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined in flowing air at a heating rate of 5 °C/min followed by an isothermal step at 550 °C for 5 h. Wet impregnation was used as a standard method to synthesize europium-supported catalysts. An appropriate amount of Eu(NO3)3∙6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.9%) was dissolved in 25 ml of ethanol and added to the supports. All catalysts were synthesized with 23 wt% europium content. The materials were periodically sonicated at 40 °C until the solvent was dried. The resulting material was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined at 550 °C in flowing air at a heating rate of 5 °C/min and an isothermal step for 5 h. The catalysts were pretreated before characterization and reaction for 1 h in a flow of HCl to convert Eu2O3 into EuOCl. The pretreated catalysts were named EuOCl/S, where S denotes the support. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were acquired using a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan) apparatus. The samples were outgassed at 200 °C for 2 h before each measurement. The surface areas of the catalysts were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method. The total pore volumes of the catalysts were calculated as P/P0 = 0.99. The crystal structures of the catalysts were investigated using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements conducted in a D -Max2500-PC (Rigaku) instrument using Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 Å, 50 kV, 100 mA). The XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded in the range of 20.0 ˚−80.0 ˚. The europium and chlorine contents were investigated using energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (SEM-EDX). Temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) analysis was performed using a BELCAT-II unit equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The catalysts (50 mg) were pretreated under a flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h in a U-shaped quartz reactor. After the pretreatment process, the furnace temperature was cooled to room temperature and increased to 900 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min under a mixed flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min) and hydrogen (2 mL/min). Hydrogen consumption was measured using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted using a VG Multilab 2000 spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corporation) with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). Temperature-programmed desorption of ethylene (C2H4-TPD) and vinyl chloride (VCM-TPD) analyses was performed using mass chromatography (5975 MSD Series, Agilent). In the case of C2H4-TPD, the catalysts (50 mg) were pretreated with nitrogen (20 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h in a U-shaped quartz reactor. After the pretreatment process, C2H4 adsorption proceeded under a flow of ethylene (5 mL/min, 5 vol%) for 1 h, and then the catalysts were treated under a flow of nitrogen (10 mL/min) at 100 °C for 1 h. Finally, the furnace temperature was increased to 500 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of nitrogen (20 mL/min). Ethylene desorption was detected using a mass detector (m/z = 27). VCM-TPD underwent the same process as C2H4-TPD and VCM desorption was detected with a mass detector (m/z = 62). Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) analysis was performed using mass chromatography (5975 MSD Series, Agilent). The catalysts (50 mg) were loaded into a U-shaped quartz reactor, pretreated in He (20 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h, and cooled to 50 °C in He. Ammonia was adsorbed at 50 °C with 5 vol% NH3/He for 1 h followed by pretreatment at 100 °C for 1 h to remove physisorbed NH3. Desorption of chemisorbed NH3 was monitored in the range of 50–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a He flow of 20 mL/min. Ammonia desorption was detected using a mass detector (m/z = 17). Element analysis (EA-CHNS) was conducted using TruSpec Micro CHNS. 2.3 Catalytic tests The oxychlorination reaction of ethylene was performed at ambient pressure in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. The gas reaction system consisted of mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst) to introduce C2H4, O2, HCl, N2 as a carrier gas, Ne as an internal standard at a 100 mL/min total volumetric flow (FT), and an electronic syringe pump to inject liquid EDC (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.8%). To neutralize the acidic component, the effluent gas was passed through an NaOH solution. The catalysts (Wcat = 0.5 g) were loaded into the reactor and heated to 400 °C in N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The loaded catalysts were examined after exposure to the designated feed composition (Table 1 ) for an hour. Ethylene and chlorinated compounds in the effluent gas (C2H4, C2H3Cl, C2H4Cl2, and C2H2Cl2) were quantified using a flame-ionized detector in an on-line gas chromatograph, equipped with a DB-VRX column. Other compounds in the effluent gas, such as Ne, O2, N2, CO, and CO2, were quantified using a TCD equipped with Molecular Sieve 13X and Porapak N columns. The conversion of reactant, yield and selectivity of products was calculated using the following equations, where Xi, Si, Yi, ni and NC,j represent the conversion, selectivity, yield, stoichiometric factor and the number of carbon atoms in the compound for carbon-containing products, respectively. (1) X i = n i inlet − n i outlet n i inlet × 100 % (2) S j = n j outlet × N C , j ∑ n j outlet × N C , j × 100 % (3) Y j = X i × S j 100 % The oxidation of HCl was performed according to the conditions listed in Table 1. The conversion of HCl was quantified by iodometric titration of Cl2. The outlet gas was bubbled through a 0.25 M aqueous KI solution (Samchun, 99.5%), and then titrated with 0.05 N sodium thiosulfate solution (Supelco) using starch solution as the indicator. The conversion of HCl was calculated using the following equation. (4) X HCl = 2 n C l 2 outlet n H C l inlet × 100 % The dehydrochlorination of EDC was conducted under the conditions listed in Table 1. At such a relatively low reaction temperature, there is almost no CO or CO2 production resulting from overoxidation. Therefore, the molar flow of the injected EDC was calculated as the sum of the EDC and VCM molar flow of the outlet gas. (5) X E D C = n V C M outlet n E D C outlet + n V C M outlet × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts The specific surface areas of the supports and the fresh EuOCl supported catalysts were analyzed. As summarized in Table 2 , the bulk and supported catalysts except EuOCl/Y showed IV-type isotherms which indicates mesoporous structure. The isotherm of EuOCl/Y exhibited I-type hysteresis which indicates the well-developed microporous structure. For the case of supported catalysts, the surface areas and pore volume decreased due to the pore blockage by europium species. SEM-EDX analysis was carried out to calculate the EuOCl content of the catalysts (Fig. S1). Table 2 shows the EuOCl content in wt.%. Compared to the nominal content (23 wt.%), the results indicated that europium species were successfully introduced to various supports by the impregnation method. Catalysts using Al2O3, TiO2, and zeolite Y as the support showed slightly lower EuOCl content than the nominal content, while, EuOCl/SiO2 showed the lowest EuOCl (18.9 wt.%). Cl/Eu ratio was also calculated to confirm the generation of EuOCl species from Eu2O3. The supported catalysts showed slightly higher Cl to Eu ratios than EuOCl because of the additional Cl adsorption on the support material. XRD analysis was performed to investigate the crystal structures of bulk EuOCl and supported catalysts. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of bulk EuOCl, EuOCl/Al2O3, EuOCl/TiO2, EuOCl/SiO2, EuOCl/ZrO2, and EuOCl/Y. Bulk EuOCl showed main diffraction peaks at 26.9 ˚, 32.2 ˚, 35.0 ˚, 45.4 ˚, 53.8 ˚, and 59.3 ˚, corresponding to the cubic EuOCl structure (ICDD PDF 73–7281). Interestingly, despite the high Eu content of 23 wt%, the diffraction peaks of EuOCl were not observed in the XRD patterns of the supported catalysts regardless of the type of support, indicating that europium exists in a highly dispersed state. XPS analysis was conducted to confirm the state of the Eu species. Fig. 2 shows the Eu 4d5/2 and Eu 4d3/2 peaks of bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts pretreated with HCl and fresh Eu2O3. Both Eu 4d peaks of the catalysts pretreated with HCl were shifted to a high binding energy of 2 eV, which is assigned to the formation of EuOCl because chlorine is a highly electronegative element [23]. Hence, it was confirmed that Eu2O3 was converted to EuOCl in the supported and bulk catalysts after HCl pretreatment [25]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of EuOCl catalysts in ethylene oxychlorination The catalytic performance of the bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts was evaluated in ethylene oxychlorination. Fig. 3 (a) shows the ethylene conversion, while Fig. 3(b) shows the VCM selectivity at 400 °C with time on stream. The detailed results of the catalytic performance in ethylene oxychlorination are summarized in Table 3 . All catalysts except EuOCl/Y retained stable catalytic activity during the reaction for 24 h. EuOCl/Y showed a gradual decrease in ethylene conversion and VCM selectivity after reaction for 12 h, indicating that the catalyst supported on Y undergoes deactivation with time-on-stream. Therefore, the catalytic performance of the EuOCl catalysts changed depending on the type of support. In the case of ethylene conversion, although the content of europium was 23% compared to bulk EuOCl, all supported EuOCl catalysts showed higher conversion than bulk EuOCl, indicating improved catalytic efficiency of the Eu atom. EuOCl/SiO2 and EuOCl/ZrO2 exhibited slightly higher ethylene conversions than bulk EuOCl, while the VCM selectivity was lower because of the high C2H5Cl (EC) selectivity of 7−10%. The EuOCl/Al2O3, EuOCl/TiO2 and EuOCl/Y catalysts showed significant enhancements in ethylene conversion and VCM selectivity compared to the bulk EuOCl catalyst. Some highly reactive catalysts produced overchlorinated products such as C2H2Cl2 (DCE). EuOCl/Y showed the highest ethylene conversion and VCM selectivity where 6% of DCE was produced, and 2% of DCE was produced over EuOCl/Al2O3. Production of COx was not observed in any of the EuOCl catalysts, because europium species have redox properties that activate ethylene and HCl but do not cause overoxidation of products such as COx [23]. As previously discussed, the process of directly producing VCM from ethylene on EuOCl-based catalysts is a stepwise reaction consisting of consecutive elementary reactions and undesirable side reactions, as shown in Fig. 4 [26]. The reaction starts with the oxychlorination of ethylene to EDC (Step 1), and sequential dehydrochlorination of EDC to yield VCM (Step 2). EC is generated by the chlorination of ethylene (Step 3), and DCE is produced by additional oxychlorination of VCM (Step 4) or oxidation of EDC (Step 5). To observe the activity of the catalysts in each elementary reaction, two elementary reactions were performed (Table 1). Firstly, the HCl oxidation reaction was conducted to check the activation ability to cleave the HCl bond because both HCl oxidation and ethylene oxychlorination reactions require HCl activation under similar reaction conditions (Fig. S2). Fig. 5 a shows the rate of ethylene consumption in oxychlorination as a function of the rate of HCl oxidation at 400 °C over bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts. A positive correlation between the two reaction rates was observed, indicating that the ability to activate HCl was proportional to the activity of the catalyst in ethylene oxychlorination. Therefore, the activity of a catalyst in ethylene oxychlorination is influenced by its ability to activate both ethylene and HCl. Secondly, the EDC dehydrochlorination reaction was conducted on bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts as the reaction temperature increased from 240 °C to 420 °C. Fig. 5b shows the selectivity of VCM as a function of the temperature at which 50% conversion is achieved in EDC dehydrochlorination (T50). We confirmed that the catalysts promoting the dehydrochlorinaiton of EDC at lower temperatures have higher VCM selectivity in ethylene oxychlorination. Therefore, the negative correlation between T50 of EDC dehydrochlorination and VCM selectivity in ethylene oxychlorination indicates that the catalyst with high VCM selectivity in ethylene oxychlorination also has superior activity for EDC dehydrochlorination. 3.3 Analyses of catalytic properties affecting ethylene oxychlorination 3.3.1 Redox property and oxidation state of europium species Previous research has indicated that the redox property of the catalyst plays an important role in the production of EDC by oxychlorination of ethylene [15–23]. During the oxychlorination reaction, the active metal is reduced during the transfer of chlorine to ethylene [6,24]. After the reduced active metal returns to its original state through a series of oxidation processes, it participates in the reaction [6, 24]. Therefore, catalysts with high redox properties tend to show high activity in the oxychlorination of ethylene. To measure the redox properties of the bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts, H2-TPR measurements were performed. The H2-TPR profile of bulk EuOCl (Fig. 6 ) displayed hydrogen consumption peaks at 601 °C and 834 °C. Each peak corresponds to the reduction of the near-surface oxygen species and bulk oxygen species, respectively [27]. The H2-TPR profiles of all EuOCl supported catalysts showed a low intensity of peaks originating from the reduction of bulk oxygen species. These results indicate that most of the EuOCl particles exist in a highly dispersed state, which corresponds well with the XRD results. It was also observed that the H2 consumption peak of surface oxygen species shifted depending on the type of support. The H2 consumption temperature decreased in the order of bulk EuOCl (601 °C) > EuOCl/ZrO2 (599 °C) > EuOCl/SiO2 (597 °C) > EuOCl/TiO2 (587 °C) > EuOCl/Al2O3 (584 °C) > EuOCl/Y (576 °C). As expected, it was confirmed that the reducibility of europium species was improved on the supported catalysts. Moreover, the catalysts reduced at low temperatures showed a high conversion of ethylene. XPS analysis was conducted to investigate the detailed oxidation state of the europium species. Investigation of Eu 3d5/2 spectra revealed that the oxidation state of europium species varies depending on the presence or type of support [28,29]. EuOCl/Y exhibited the lowest Eu3+ fraction, followed by EuOCl/ Al2O3, EuOCl/TiO2, EuOCl/ZrO2, EuOCl/SiO2 and bulk EuOCl (Fig. 7 ). This order of decreasing Eu3+ fraction and increasing Eu2+ fraction agrees well with the ethylene conversion. These results are related to the oxygen vacancies that act as adsorption sites for ethylene. As the active metal is in a more reduced state, the number of oxygen vacancies increases [29,30]. Therefore, the catalyst that exhibits a higher Eu2+ fraction has more oxygen vacancies and activates ethylene and HCl more easily (Fig. 5a). In addition to the redox property, the adsorption behavior of ethylene also affects the ethylene oxychlorination step. It has been reported that the adsorption energies of ethylene and chlorinated products such as EDC, VCM, EC, and DCE depend on the surface environment of the catalyst, and such changes in adsorption energy affect the reaction activity of the catalysts in each reaction step [26]. Because ethylene generally has the weakest adsorption energy among all reactants and products, the change in the adsorption behavior of ethylene is one of the factors affecting the activity of the oxychlorination reaction. For ethylene to adsorb well, the presence of oxygen vacancies or chlorinated vacancies is required [26]. To elucidate the adsorption properties of ethylene, C2H4-TPD analysis was conducted. As shown in Table 4 , the catalysts supported over Y, Al2O3, and TiO2 exhibited relatively larger amounts of adsorbed ethylene than the rest of the catalysts. This tendency is also consistent with the results of XPS analysis, as the europium species is in a reductive state, and the number of oxygen vacancies that function as adsorption sites for ethylene increases. It was also observed that supported EuOCl catalysts adsorb ethylene more strongly than bulk EuOCl. EuOCl/Y was found to absorb ethylene with the strongest bond. The adsorbed ethylene desorbed at 183 °C, which is higher than the desorption temperature of bulk EuOCl (162 °C) by 21 °C. EuOCl/Al2O3 (178 °C) and EuOCl/TiO2 (175 °C) exhibited slight differences. EuOCl/SiO2 (168 °C) and EuOCl/ZrO2 (164 °C) exhibited similar adsorption intensities to bulk EuOCl (Fig. 8 ). These results suggest that the presence and type of support changes not only the number of vacancies but also the properties of vacancies, which determine the adsorption strength of ethylene. 3.3.2 . Acidic property of catalysts The acidic properties of the catalysts play an important role in the dehydrochlorination of EDC to produce the desired product, VCM [21–23]. The catalyst with large number of acid sites exhibited high catalytic activity in the EDC dehydrochlorination reaction at low temperatures [29]. However, it has been shown that if acidity is excessive, coke formation by additional chlorination or oligomerization is promoted, which adversely affects the long-term activity of the catalysts [29]. To examine the acidic properties of the bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts, NH3-TPD analysis was performed. The supports and supported catalysts were analyzed to determine the changes in the acidic properties caused by the loading of EuOCl. The europium-supported catalysts showed substantial increases in total acidity as summarized in Table 5 . The NH3-TPD profiles of the supported catalysts showed that the trend of increasing acid sites differed on the support (Fig. 9 ). EuOCl/Al2O3, EuOCl/TiO2, and EuOCl/Y exhibited higher NH3 desorption amounts over 400 °C than the other catalysts. EuOCl/Al2O3 showed the highest number of acid sites over 400 °C, whereas EuOCl/Y exhibited the highest total acidity. The supported catalysts showed higher total acidity than bulk EuOCl because of the high dispersion of europium and the influence of the support. Fig. 10 shows the VCM selectivity and carbon deposition amount after 24 h of reaction as a function of the amount of total acidity. Both VCM selectivity and carbon deposition amount were positively correlated with the total acidity. It was revealed that the amount of carbon deposited on EuOCl/Y was extremely high compared to other supported EuOCl catalysts. This carbon deposition is responsible for the deactivation of EuOCl/Y after 12 h of reaction. To confirm the effect of the acid properties of the catalyst on the catalytic dehydrochlorination of EDC, EDC dehydrochlorination was performed at temperatures between 240 and 420 °C (Fig. 11 ). Bulk EuOCl started to show reactivity at 285 °C and showed 100% conversion of EDC at 410 °C. The supported EuOCl catalysts showed higher reactivity than bulk EuOCl which achieved 100% conversion of EDC at lower temperatures. The catalytic activity of the catalysts decreased in the order EuOCl/Y (320 °C) > EuOCl/Al2O3 (335 °C) > EuOCl/TiO2 (365 °C) > EuOCl/SiO2 (380 °C) > EuOCl/ZrO2 (395 °C) > EuOCl (410 °C). Catalytic activity of EDC dehydrochlorination is inversely proportional to T50 and consistent with the VCM selectivity. This shows that the acidic properties of the catalysts are strongly correlated with the conversion of EDC to VCM (Fig. 5b). 3.3.3 Additional reaction of VCM generating DCE Among the supported EuOCl catalysts, the EuOCl/Al2O3 and EuOCl/Y catalysts exhibited high selectivity for DCE. Although several mechanisms by which DCE is produced are known, the main pathway is Cl uptake by the additional reaction of VCM [26]. This mechanism is related to the adsorption behavior of VCMs. On the surface where oxygen vacancies or chlorinated vacancies exist, the adsorption strength of VCM is lower than that of other products such as EDC, EC, and DCE. Therefore, the intermediate product does not desorb well until VCM is formed, after which it is easily desorbed and does not undergo an additional reaction, resulting in high VCM selectivity [26]. VCM-TPD analysis was performed to investigate the adsorption energy of VCM on bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts. As shown in Fig. 12 , EuOCl/Y and EuOCl/Al2O3 which produced DCE more abundantly, exhibited higher desorption temperatures. The EuOCl/Y catalyst showed the highest VCM desorption temperature (221 °C) and adsorption amount compared to the other catalysts, which explains the high DCE selectivity of 6%. (Table 4) In addition, since the reaction producing DCE is also a reaction in which Cl is transferred from activated HCl, it is affected by the redox properties of the catalysts. EuOCl/Y and EuOCl/Al2O3 having higher redox properties demonstrated the higher HCl consumption rate than other catalysts as shown in Fig. 5a. Therefore, to inhibit the generation of DCE, the redox properties should be optimized to an appropriate level. These results confirm that the main generation pathway of DCE is Cl uptake by the additional reaction of VCM, meaning that rapid desorption of VCM is an important step in inhibiting additional DCE production. 4 Conclusions In this study, the effect of introducing support into the EuOCl catalyst was investigated for the direct production of VCM from ethylene. All support materials were modified with 23 wt% Eu, using the same evaporation impregnation procedure without any promoter. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts changed by impregnation of EuOCl on various supports improved the catalytic activity (at 400 °C, 6−18% ethylene conversion, 70−90% VCM, selectivity). The redox properties of the bulk and supported EuOCl catalysts were investigated to determine the activity of the oxychlorination step. The results of H2-TPR and XPS analyses demonstrated that as more europium species were in a reductive state, the activation of reactants was more likely. As the rate-determining step, this leads to a high conversion rate of ethylene and HCl. The adsorption energy of ethylene was also explained the reactivity of the catalysts. Through the C2H4-TPD analysis, we confirmed that the amount or property of vacancies changed according to the type of support, because oxygen vacancies were affected by the oxidation state of the active metal. The acidic properties of the catalysts were studied to elucidate the dehydrochlorination of EDC in the VCM step. The acidity of the catalysts was enhanced by the impregnation of europium, and it was found that medium or strong acid sites promoted EDC dehydrochlorination. VCM-TPD analysis was performed to explain the generation of DCE, an overchlorinated product, in some catalysts. EuOCl/Y and EuOCl/Al2O3, which produced DCE, exhibited a high desorption energy of VCM, which increased the frequency of the additional reaction to DCE. Through various analyses, factors affecting each reaction step of VCM production from ethylene and the effect of introducing the support were revealed. In particular, the EuOCl/Al2O3 catalyst, which has excellent redox properties, adsorption behavior, and appropriate acidity showed excellent catalytic performance in ethylene oxychlorination. coredata.dc:description: A series of supported EuOCl catalysts, and bulk EuOCl catalyst were selected for ethylene oxychlorination with HCl to produce a VCM. The supported EuOCl catalysts showed higher ethylene conversion and VCM yield than those of bulk EuOCl despite the low Eu content. The EuOCl/Y catalysts demonstrated the highest ethylene conversion and VCM selectivity followed by EuOCl/Al2O3. The catalysts were characterized in terms of redox properties, acidic properties, and adsorption behavior of the reactant and product. The reduction temperature of europium species decreased when EuOCl was loaded on various supports. The activity of HCl oxidation is strongly related to the improved redox properties, resulting in better activation of the reactant. We demonstrated that the number of acidic sites was proportional to the dehydrochlorination activity of EDC. Investigation of the adsorption behavior of C2H4 showed that the number of oxygen vacancies increased on the supported EuOCl catalysts. EuOCl/Y and EuOCl/Al2O3 catalysts, showed good catalytic performance, exhibited better redox and acidic properties, and had higher amounts of oxygen vacancies than the other catalysts. However, EuOCl/Y with excessively high acidity showed deactivation with time-on-stream owing to carbon deposition. Therefore, EuOCl/Al2O3 was found to be the most suitable supported catalyst for the oxychlorination of ethylene.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced activity and selectivity of supported europium oxychloride catalysts for ethylene oxychlorination with HCl

dcterms:subject.$: Direct production of VCM from ethylene
